module.p: Nouns are words which typically describe or identify tangible material entities – people, animals, artifacts, substances, places .

Nouns are divided into two groups, depending on the way in which they relate to the entities they describe or identify –
Proper nouns are names of particular entities – Raonaid
Rachel, Glaschu
Glasgow, Laideann
Latin.
Common nouns describe classes of entity – bean
woman, cànan
language, uisge
water.

section.p:
Nouns have number – every noun form is either singular or plural –
Ealasaid Elizabeth, clach stone and fìon wine are all singular noun forms.
leabraichean books, balaich boys and uinneagan windows are all plural noun forms. Note that proper nouns are always singular and never plural. Common nouns tend to have both singular and plural forms – leabhar book ~ leabhraichean books, balach boy ~ balaich boys.

p.ed: Add note on legacy dual number here?

section.p:
Singular nouns have gender – every singular noun form (including those describing inanimate entities) is either feminine or masculine –
Nirribhidh Norway, caileag girl and sùil eye are all feminine singular noun forms.
Dòmhnall Donald, baile town and airgead silver, money are all masculine singular noun forms. Note that the gender of inanimate nouns is unpredictable from their meaning.

p.ed: Add note on (historical) neuter gender here?

section.p:
Nouns have case – every noun form is either nominative or dative or genitive –
The genitive form of the masculine singular proper noun Seòras George is Sheòrais; the nominative and dative forms are just Seòras.
The (traditional) dative form of the feminine singular common noun bean woman is mnaoi, and the genitive is mnatha.
The genitive form of the plural common noun form coin dogs is con, and the dative is just coin.

p.ed: Add note on vocative ‘case’ here? And (historical) accusatives?

section.p: Pronouns are noun-like words which refer to specific entities identifiable from (linguistic or extralinguistic) context – sinn we, us, ise she, her, seo this (thing).

A noun can have one or more modifiers, which are either –
an (attributive) adjective – taigh geal a white house, Màiri Bhàn Niseach Fair-haired Mary from Ness
a genitive common noun – cù taighe a house dog, taigh chon a kennel (lit. dogs’ house)
a preposition (phrase) – caileag le falt fada a girl with long hair, Dòmhnall à Lunnainn Donald from London
a relative clause – leabhar a sgrìobh mi a book which I wrote, taigh nach do cheannaich sinn a house which we didn’t buy

Noun modifiers (adjectives or genitive common nouns) are lenited in the following cases –
modifiers of nominative feminine (singular) nouns –
caileag mhòr shona a big happy girl
Màiri Bhàn bhòidheach beautiful Fair-haired Mary
clach mhuillinn dhubh a black millstone [alt. clach-mhuillinn dhubh]
caora bheag Shasannach a small English sheep
Mòrag chridhe beloved Sarah okay?
modifiers of dative feminine (singular) nouns –
le caileig mhòir shona with a big happy girl [alt. le caileag mhòr shona]
air Màiri Bhàin bhòidhich on beautiful Fair-haired Mary [alt. air Màiri Bhàn bhòidheach]
ri cloich mhuillinn dhuibh against a black millstone [alt. ri clach-mhuillinn dhubh]
aig caora bhig Shasannaich at a small English sheep [alt. aig caora bheag Shasannach]
do Mhòraig chridhe to beloved Sarah [alt. do Mhòrag chridhe]
modifiers of genitive masculine (singular) nouns –
ceann balaich mhòir chrosta a big naughty boy’s (head)
bean Sheumais Bhig bhochd poor Little James’ (wife)
doras taighe thasgaidh dhùthchail a rural museum’s (door) [alt. doras taighe-thasgaidh dhùthchail]
curran bodaich shneachda ghil a white snowman’s carrot [alt. curran bodaich-shneacha ghil]
claidheamh Ghriogail chridhe beloved Gregor’s sword okay?
modifiers of slenderised (non-genitive) plural (common) nouns –
(le) balaich mhòra chrosta (with) naughty big boys
(air) bodaich shneachda gheala (on) white snowmen [alt. (air) bodaich-shneachda gheala]
(aig) caoraich bheaga Shasannach (at) small English sheep grammatical?
modifiers of all (singular common) nouns pre-specified by the leniting definite article a’ (or an fh-), including lenited dative masculines –
leis a’ bhalach mhòr chrosta with the naughty big boy
aig a’ bhodach shneachda gheal at the white snowman [alt. aig a’ bhodach-shneachda gheal]
but – anns an taigh thasgaidh dhùthchail
genitive plural nouns modifying another noun are always lenited –
(ann an) taigh chon mòr (in) a large kennel [alt. (ann an) taigh-chon mòr]
(anns) an taigh chon mòr (in) the large kennel
mullach (an) taighe chon mhòir a (the) large kennel’s roof
(ann an) taighean chon mòra (in) large kennels
(anns) na taighean chon mòra (in) the large kennels
mullaich (nan) taighean chon mòra (the) large kennels’ roofs
modifiers of (common) nouns pre-numerated by dà two are always lenited –
(an) dà bhalach mhòr chrosta (the) two naughty big boys
guthan (an) dà chaileige mhòire shona (the) two big happy girls’ voices [alt. guthan dà chaileig mhòir shona] ??
need more examples here?

Noun modifiers (adjectives or genitive common nouns) are not lenited in the following cases –
modifiers of nominative masculine (singular) nouns –
balach mòr crosta a naughty big boy
Seumas Beag bochd poor Little James
taigh tasgaidh dùthchail a rural museum [alt. taigh-tasgaidh dùthchail]
bodach sneachda geal a white snowman [alt. bodach-sneachda geal]
Griogal cridhe beloved Gregor
modifiers of dative masculine (singular) nouns not pre-specified by the definite article –
le balach mòr crosta with a naughty big boy
air Seumas Beag bochd on poor Little James
ann an taigh tasgaidh dùthchail in a rural museum [alt. ann an taigh-tasgaidh dùthchail]
aig bodach sneachda geal at a white snowman [alt. aig bodach-sneachda geal]
do Ghriogal cridhe to beloved Gregor
modifiers of unlenited dative masculine (singular) (common) nouns pre-specified by the definite article –
anns an taigh tasgaidh dùthchail in the rural museum
modifiers of genitive feminine (singular) nouns –
guth caileige mòire sona a big happy girl’s voice [alt. guth caileig mhòir shona]
ad Màiri Bàine bòidh[i]che beautiful Fair-haired Mary’s hat [alt. ad Màiri Bhàin bhòidhich] not sure here
coltas cloiche muillinn duibhe a black millstone’s appearance [alt. coltas cloich-mhuillinn dhuibh]
màthair caorach bige Sasannaiche a small English sheep’s mother [alt. màthair caorach bhig Shasannaich] not sure here
cù Mòraig cridhe beloved Sarah’s dog okay?
modifiers of non-slenderised plural (common) nouns (incl. all genitive plurals) –
(ann an) taighean tasgaidh dùthchail (in) rural museums [alt. (ann an) taighean-tasgaidh dùthchail]
(le) caileagan mòra sona (with) happy big girls
(air) clachan muillinn dubha (on) black millstones [alt. (air) clachan-muillinn dubha]
dorsan t[h]aighean tasgaidh dùthchail rural museum’s doors [alt. dorsan t[h]aighean-tasgaidh dùthchail] lenition with indefinite specifiers?
guthan c[h]aileag[an] mòra sona happy big girls’ voices
coltas c[h]lach[an] muillinn dubha black millstones’ appearance [alt. coltas c[h]lachan-muillinn dubha]
màthraichean c[h]aorach beaga Sasannach small English sheep’s mothers
cinn b[h]alach mòra crosta naughty big boys’ heads
currain b[h]odach sneachda geala white snowmen’s carrots [alt. currain b[h]odach-sneachda geala]

A noun can have a specifier, which is either –
a determiner as pre-specifier – an taigh the house, ar cù our dog
a (usually genitive) noun as post-specifier – taigh a’ mhinisteir the minister’s house, Màiri Sheumais James’ Mary. Note that a proper noun cannot have a pre-specifier, cf. mo Mhàiri-sa ~ Màiri agamsa my Mary.

Two nouns can stand in apposition (under certain conditions), agreeing for case (and number) – Dòmhnall an sagart Èireannach Donald the Irish priest, Glaschu – baile mòr nan Gàidheal Glasgow, the city of the Gaels.

The main uses of nominative noun forms are –
to introduce the subject of a verb – tha cù agam I have a dog
to introduce the object of a verb – chunnaic i Seumas she saw James.

The main use of dative noun forms is –
to introduce the complement of a preposition – fon chraoibh under the tree, le mnaoi with a woman.

The main uses of genitive noun forms are –
to introduce the specifier of another noun – taigh Sheumais James’ house
to introduce a common noun which modifies a preceding common noun – taigh chon kennel.

section.p:
When a noun form is associated with a material (tangible) sense, it is being used as a concrete noun –
Tha taigh aig Raonaid Rachel has a house – both the common noun taigh house and the proper noun Raonaid Rachel are being used as concrete nouns here.

When a noun form is associated with a non-material sense, it is being used as an abstract noun –
Is e cànan clasaigeach a tha ann an Laideann Latin is a classical language – both the common noun cànan language and the proper noun Laideann Latin are being used as abstract nouns here.

p.ed: Still need clarification on whether ‘Laideann’ or ‘Laidinn’ is better in nominative.

section.p:
Most nouns are generally either predominantly concrete or predominantly abstract. However some can be either depending on context –
Tha Dòmhnall a’ sgrìobhadh leabhair Donald is writing a book – the (genitive singular) noun leabhair book is being used as an abstract noun here, denoting a unit of information. [alt. Tha Dòmhnall a’ sgrìobhadh leabhar]
Tha Dòmhnall a’ sgrìobhadh ann an leabhar Donald is writing in a book – the (dative singular) noun leabhar is being used as a concrete noun here, denoting a material object.

When a (singular) noun form is associated with a ‘bounded’ sense, it is being used as a countable noun –
Tha cù aig Raonaid Rachel has a dog – cù dog is associated with a simple bounded sense here (ie. an individual), and hence is being used as a countable noun.
Tha treud air a’ mhonadh There is a herd on the moor – treud herd is associated with a complex bounded sense here (ie. a group of animals), and hence is also being used as a countable noun.

When a (singular, common) noun form is associated with a non-bounded sense, it is being used as an uncountable noun –
Tha Raonaid ag òl fìona Rachel is drinking wine – the (genitive singular) noun form fìona wine is associated with a simple non-bounded sense here (ie. a substance), and hence is being used as an uncountable noun (more precisely a ‘mass’ noun). [alt. Tha Raonaid ag òl fìon.]
Bha crodh air a’ mhonadh There were cattle on the moor – the noun crodh cattle is associated with a complex non-bounded sense here (ie. an aggregate of cows), and hence is being used as an uncountable noun (more precisely a ‘collective’, singulare tantum, noun).

Note that proper nouns are only used with bounded (countable) senses. Note also that plural (common) nouns are usually associated with non-bounded, complex senses –
Tha coin aig Mairead. Margaret has dogs.
